title-group.subtitle: A Reassessment of the (Putative) Pitfalls of Multi-value QCA

abstract.p: In a recent contribution to this journal, Vink and van Vliet seek to raise researchers’ awareness of the potentials and pitfalls of multi-value Qualitative Comparative Analysis (MvQCA). The authors are unconvinced by the technique’s distinctness from the more established crisp-set QCA (csQCA) and fuzzy-set QCA (fsQCA) variants and question its added value to configurational comparative methodology on five points. This article demonstrates why none of them challenges mvQCA. Two points do not relate to the method, two are based on incorrect reasoning, and one results from a misunderstanding of notational systems. This comment seeks to prove the suspicion against mvQCA that has prevailed thus far in the literature unjustified. It argues that this variant is as useful a contribution to the toolbox of comparative social science methodology as csQCA and fsQCA.

sec.title: A Short Biography of MVQCA
sec.p: Multi-value QCA (mvQCA)—the youngest member of the QCA family of comparative configurational techniques—has had a hard time so far. Textbooks and articles have questioned its status as a set-theoretic method (e.g., Schneider and Wagemann 2012; Vink and van Vliet [VvV] 2009), and literature reviews show that between the years 2004, when it was introduced by Cronqvist (2004), and 2011, it has been applied to a substantive research question in only seven peer-reviewed journal articles (Thiem and Duşa 2013). What's the explanation for this? It could be that in many cases, mvQCA has simply been inappropriate for the kind of data researchers sought to analyze. Perhaps the available software is deficient in some important respects, or mvQCA is somehow methodologically inferior to the more developed csQCA and fsQCA variants.

None of these conjectures has enough traction to account for the disproportionate underutilization of mvQCA. First, it is more than doubtful that base variables in the social sciences have only rarely required the application of mvQCA. Profession, religious denomination, colonial background, and regime type are all common examples of multinomial base variables. Second, although the Tosmana software (Cronqvist 2011) lacks some basic functionality, all essential procedures are, in fact, available. The third point, however, has to be taken seriously insofar as the claim made in the methodological literature that mvQCA offers no added value has very likely deterred potential end users. For example, Hartmann and Kemmerzell (2010:645) qualify their methodological choice by emphasizing that they “are fully aware of the criticisms raised against MV-QCA.”

This comment reveals that many of these criticisms are unjustified. In particular, it addresses the five points raised by VvV (2009) and echoed by Schneider and Wagemann (2012), that mvQCA has no added value over csQCA and fsQCA, and that its status as a distinct set-theoretic method is, at best, in doubt. In the following, I recapitulate and subsequently address these five points.

sec.title: The (Putative) Pitfalls of MVQCA
sec.p:
First, VvV (2009:270) argue that the problem mvQCA was initially introduced to address—namely, the calibration of sets from multinomial base variables—has been almost nonexistent in the literature. To support their case, the authors analyze a set of studies that have used mvQCA, including two working papers, three methodological articles, but only two substantive applications. As the second and third points are closely related to each other, they are summarized together. VvV (2009:271) suggest that all mvQCA applications could be constructed as csQCA applications with one fewer additional condition than the number of categories for the original multi-value condition. All impossible logical remainders that result from this transposition should then be excluded. Fourth, VvV point out that in many cases, theoretical expectations eliminate the need for the creation of multi-value sets. Often, these expectations can be directly operationalized by traditional crisp sets. And finally, but most consequentially, VvV (2009:272) hold that “the most important downside of mvQCA is arguably that it is difficult to understand in set-theoretic terms.”
Claim 1: Continuous base variables, not categorical ones, have often been transformed into multi-value sets, thereby eliminating the main reason for which mvQCA has been developed in the first place.

Note: GDP = gross domestic product.VvV’s first point of criticism appears justified. Eight of the 15 conditions used in these applications have been calibrated from continuous (interval or ratio scale) base variables, whereas 7 have been calibrated from categorical (ordinal or nominal scale) base variables. A simple comparison of these numbers, however, is a deceptive indicator. The reason lies in the current conceptual separation of crisp-set, multi-value, and fuzzy-set data types, which has also led to separate computational routines for processing them.

When core explanatory factors are operationalized on categorical base variables from which multi-value sets are to be calibrated, researchers have no choice but to also transform additional base variables into multi-value or crisp sets even if they are continuous. The argument that mvQCA has often been used with continuous base variables must, therefore, be set in relation to the base variables of all other conditions, the core explanatory conditions in particular. For example, the nominally scaled base variable “toll-rate approach” used by Gross and Garvin (2011) comprises three categories. If mvQCA is to be used, there is no alternative within the current methodological framework of QCA to also categorizing the ratio-scaled base variable “concession length” because multi-value and fuzzy sets cannot yet be processed together.

MvQCA is ill-used, however, when at least one base variable is continuous and all other are either dichotomous or also continuous. In these cases, fsQCA should always be preferred over mvQCA because the transformation of continuous base variables into categories leads to an unnecessary loss of information. In summary, Claim 1 solely concerns data transformation issues, but is unrelated to mvQCA as a method.
Claims 2 and 3: No added benefit is to be gained from mvQCA because csQCA can always be used instead, with impossible logical remainders excluded from the analysis.

To show why these claims are incorrect in conjunction, consider Table 2 and its corresponding Figure 1. Table 2 shows two truth tables, TTmv on the left-hand side with the crisp condition CS and the multi-value condition MV, and TTcs on the right-hand side with the same information transposed to a truth table with two auxiliary crisp conditions MV0 and MV1, each of which corresponds to the respective category of the multi-value set MV in TTmv. The joint absence indicates the presence of the third category of MV, MV{2}. Configurations are indexed by Ci. As no logical remainders exist in TTmv, TTcs shows two impossible logical remainders. Configurations C7 and C8 are impossible because traditional multi-value sets have mutually exclusive categories and multiple full or partial membership is therefore ruled out. As usual, for each configuration, the OUT column contains a summary truth value of the subset relation between the configuration and the outcome set.

The Boolean minimization of (C1) then yields the complex solution with minimal sum (M1) because all categories of MV appear in (C1) and therefore render the same redundant. Prime implicant mv0CS covers areas 2 and 6, mv1CS areas 4 and 6 in Figure 1b. As a consequence, minimal sums (M1) and (M2) are clearly different. The solution to this discrepancy lies in the exclusion of the impossible logical remainders from the minimization of (C2). To arrive at (M1), area 7 has to be included, which will only happen if impossible logical remainders are allowed into the minimization process, something VvV argue should not be done. With C7 included canonical sum (C3) results.C3f1TTcs=MV0mv1CS+mv0MV1CS+mv0mv1CS+MV0MV1CS

The detailed minimization path of (C3) is shown in Figure 2. The first pass reduces (C3) to a Boolean sum with two terms, each of which consists of two condition values. After the second pass, the minimal sum has been reached. This time, it also only consists of value CS, which now equals (M2). In conclusion, if mvQCA truth tables are transposed to csQCA truth tables, impossible logical remainders must be made available for reduction in order to derive correct solutions.

In addition to the implausible necessity of making impossible logical remainders available, there are other reasons why mvQCA truth tables should not be remodeled as csQCA truth tables. First, a growth in the dimension of a truth table means that more coding work has to be carried out by the analyst. The dimension growth rate is a function of the number of multi-value sets in the data and the number of categories each of these sets consists of. Additional manual tasks, however, increase the probability of errors. Second, using a matrix of a higher dimension is inefficient if the same information can be stored in a matrix of a lower dimension. In summary, Claims 2 and 3 are incorrect insofar as the transposition of mvQCA truth tables to csQCA truth tables requires the inclusion of impossible logical remainders. Furthermore, it adds potential sources of coding errors and is less efficient.
Claim 4: mvQCA is rarely needed to capture researchers’ theoretical expectations about the relation between some condition and an outcome.

VvV use the example of traffic light colors and accidents in arguing that the creation of more than one crisp condition is unnecessary because theory would guide us to hypothesize a likely connection only between red and accidents, but not green or yellow. A single crisp condition would therefore suffice. This point of criticism is a prisoner of context. Daily experiences of the behavior of traffic participants—cars, bicycles, or pedestrians—in relation to traffic lights and the consequences that result provide us with strong theoretical expectations about the connection between accidents and traffic light color. At red, traffic participants are instructed to stop. If they do not abide by this direction, accidents may occur more often than when all participants adhere to the rules. However, it is improbable that many researchers have daily encounters with different toll-rate approaches and could easily formulate directed hypotheses about the connection between average-cost pricing, marginal social-cost pricing, or revenue-maximizing pricing and the degree of road congestion. Hence, Claim 4 is also unrelated to mvQCA as a method.
Claim 5: mvQCA is difficult to understand in set-theoretic terms.

The invalidation of the fifth claim only requires all set-data types be brought into a common notational system, not a demonstration that the principles of Boolean minimization or set-theoretic operations also hold for mvQCA because truth tables that contain traditional crisp and multi-value sets can already be processed. By convention, membership-score notation has been used for csQCA and fsQCA, but value notation is used for mvQCA. Although not comparable, parallels have been drawn between the numbers used in these two systems; consequently, much confusion has been generated, often to the disadvantage of mvQCA. But the mere use of different systems of notation does not put mvQCA’s status as a set-theoretic method in doubt. I will briefly illustrate below why a small redefinition of the existing set-data types and a more elaborate system of notation resolve the seemingly set-theoretic incongruity VvV base their fifth point of criticism on.

Currently, multi-value sets are always crisp and objects cannot be partial members of any category of a set. Therefore, they can be defined more precisely as multi-value crisp sets. From this perspective, crisp sets can be relabeled to binary-value crisp sets and fuzzy sets to binary-value fuzzy sets. Values should not be confused with set membership scores. The former only describe set categories, whereas the latter indicate the degree to which objects belong to different categories. In conjunction with an adapted system of notation, these redefinitions allow the three set-data types to be reconciled in a single set-theoretic framework.

Membership score and value notation can be unified by putting them on a common denominator, which will be called value-score notation for reasons of terminological coherence. In value-score notation, the set membership score si of some case i in value {vl} of set Sj is given by the value-score term Sj{vl}si, with i = 1, 2, …, n, l = 1, 2, …, p and j = 1, 2, …, k. Each value may be denoted by a number, letter, or any other symbol. It only has to be a unique identifier. Thus, value-score notation uses a dual structure which combines a set-value indicator with a set membership score. Table 3 presents two hypothetical data tables that incorporate all three set-data types for ten cases. Data table DT1 uses the traditional, but incompatible, systems of notation, whereas DT2 applies value-score notation. The data in DT1 cannot be processed by QCA because C1 is a binary-value crisp set, C2 a multi-value crisp set, C3 and the outcome O, however, are binary-value fuzzy sets. The meaning of “1” under C2 is different from that of the same value under any of the other sets. This difference in meaning has been the root cause of much confusion regarding mvQCA’s set-theoretic status. With value-score notation, no such incongruities arise and all summary statistics, including consistency and coverage, remain computable. Theoretically, DT2 could thus be processed without problems.

For example, case i = 1 has full nonmembership in value v2 = 1 of C1, full membership in value v1 = 0 of C2, a partial membership of 0.4 in value v2 = 1 of C3, and also a partial membership of 0.7 in value v2 = 1 of O. As C1, C3, and O are all binary-value constructs, they could as well be represented by their first value v1 = 0 because for all binary-value set-data types and any value l = z, Boolean negation implies {vz}ci = 1 − {vl≠z}ci. Replacing the representation of membership in values by Boolean negation also works for multi-value crisp sets, where {vz}ci = 1 − ({v1}ci + {v2}ci + … + {vl≠z}ci + … + {vp}ci). However, the use of any other value than the one in which a case has full membership is again less efficient. For example, the same information provided in the value-score term C2〈{v2}c1{v3}c1〉 = C2〈{1}0{2}0〉 is also contained in C2{v1}c1 = C2{0}1. In summary, mvQCA builds on crisp-set logic but extends the number of categories beyond csQCA’s two possible states. Being a generalization of csQCA, its status as a set-theoretic method cannot be in doubt.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Almost 5 years after its introduction, Vink and van Vliet (2009) have made a laudable attempt to raise researchers’ awareness of the specificities of mvQCA as an underutilized technique in the toolbox of configurational comparative methodology. In this respect, their contribution has long been overdue and should be highly welcomed. However, if points of criticism that make end users unsure of mvQCA’s usefulness as a set-theoretic method prove unfounded, more damage than good is done on that account. The main objective of this comment has been to open a more nuanced debate about the potentials and pitfalls of mvQCA. A continuation of informed exchange should eventually also lead to a more balanced application ratio between all three QCA variants.
